Exaggerate: The claim exaggerates the value of U.S. agricultural exports to China by stating it was "$16 or $17 billion" when it was actually nearly $26 billion in 2012.
Lack enough support: The claim lacks enough support as it does not provide any evidence or sources to back up the stated value of U.S. agricultural exports to China.
Contradict fact: The claim contradicts the fact that the actual "all-time high" for U.S. agricultural exports to China was not "$16 or $17 billion" but nearly $26 billion in 2012.
Problematic assumption: The claim makes a problematic assumption that the potential impact of the tentative trade deal will be significant based on the exaggerated value of U.S. agricultural exports.
Falters at times: The claim falters at times by misstating the record value of exports and presenting misleading figures for the "all-time high" and the lowest point of China's purchase of U.S. agricultural goods.
Exist alternative explanation: There is an alternative explanation provided by experts that the low figures for China's purchase of U.S. agricultural goods in 2002 were due to China becoming a member of the World Trade Organization, rather than a deliberate decrease in purchases.
